results.title: Greg
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Tom Manefield and Phil Noyce
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Why can’t they be like we were?”.
An exploration of the lifestyle of a middle-class family in an affluent suburb and the family’s attitudes to success, competitiveness, and the raising of children. Greg attends an independent school whilst his younger brother, Richard, attends a government high school. An important theme in the film is the extent to which Greg is making, or is able to make, autonomous decisions about his own life.

results.title: Greetings from Wollongong
results.creator_credit: Steel City Pictures, Nina Saunders and Mary Callaghan
results.brief_description: Set in Wollongong on the south coast of New South Wales, the film chronicles a typical day in the lives of four teenagers. Faced with problems of unemployment, limited prospects and living in a city which is overrun by consumerist culture, they seek positive ways of constructing a life for themselves.

results.title: Greetings from Wollongong
results.brief_description: Four unemployed young people roam around one of Australia’s largest industrial cities. Combines social realist fiction with an essay-like examination of the city of Wollongong. This film is equally engaging and intellectually rigorous. As an exploration of a once leading steel-producing city, now increasingly blighted by unemployment, it also becomes a requiem for post-war working class Australia.

results.title: Greetings From Iraq
results.brief_description:
I was born in 1962 in a village on the Euphrates River near Najaf in Iraq. In 1985, I graduated with a degree in applied theatre studies from the Institute of Fine Arts in Baghdad. Shortly after completing my studies I went into exile in northern Iraq: I was waiting for political change to go back home. After crossing the border from Iraq to Iran, I was arrested, imprisoned and transferred to a detention centre. I remained there for seven weeks before I was transferred to another detention centre in Tehran. I was there for 11 months.
In the detention centre there was the constant threat of being deported back to Iraq. I got a false passport and was travelling to Syria when I was arrested again for having false papers.
I escaped to the Pakistan-Iran border; I introduced myself to UNHCR (United Nations High Commission for Refugees) as an Iraqi refugee. I spent - or wasted - seven years of my life waiting for an answer from the UNHCR regarding my application for resettlement.
I was finally accepted as a refugee by Australia. In 1997, I arrived in Perth. In 2001, I became an Australian citizen. In 2003, I finished my Master of Creative Arts at Newcastle University.
In 2004, I want back to see my homeland for the first time after 17 to 18 years in exile, afterwards returning to Australia.
- Niz Jabour

Taken from PROOF exhibition 2004

results.title: Greetings
results.creator_credit: West End Film, Charles Hirsch and Brian De Palma
results.brief_description: A film very representative of the era and place in which it was made - New York late 1960s. “Greetings”, directed by Brian De Palma, is about three hip intellectual young men who come up with some novel ideas on how to avoid the draft that will send them to the conflict in Vietnam. Paul (Jonathan Warden), Jon (Robert De Niro) and Lloyd (Geritt Graham) present as gay and extreme right-wingers to the army all the while trying their best to seduce women to keep themselves occupied. This is a witty and satirical view of American culture at the time and is more a series of fun episodes in the protagonists’ lives than a straight-forward narrative. Co-written by Brian De Palma and Charles Hirsch and also edited by De Palma. Music by ‘The Children of Paradise’.

results.title: Greenprint for life
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Botanic man”.
Botanist and ecologist, David Bellamy, takes us deep into the Amazonian jungle to illustrate the complex ecosystems which have evolved there. The Indians, animals and plants exist in harmony, each dependent on the other in cycles of growth, decay and regrowth. Bellamy stresses the importance of this balance between man and nature and explains the adaptations plants have made in this hot, wet, dense environment to maximise photosynthesis, the by-product of which is the all important oxygen on which our world relies.

results.title: Greenland recent geophysical research
results.brief_description: Film shot by scientists on the 1952-54 British North Greenland Expedition has been assembled to reveal some aspects of the work. The assistant glaciologist, Peter Taylor, discusses the objects of the expedition and their findings. Describes the process of measuring the depth of the ice in the centre of Greenland and the investigation of the shape of the rock bed beneath. Further proof is added to the theory that Greenland is a vast saucer filled with ice and that the surface of the land at the centre is below sea level. The scientists also investigated whether this mass of ice is increasing or decreasing.

results.title: Greenkeeping
results.creator_credit: Central Park Films, Glenys Rowe and David Caesar
results.brief_description: One thing after another seems to have gone wrong for the not so bright greenkeeper Lenny (Mark Little). In his professional life he has to contend with brown grass, in his personal life his dope smoking wife (Lisa Hensley) is running up debts with her dealers. He tries to secure the affections of a waitress at the bowling club, but like most other aspects of his life, he lucks out. Things reach a crisis point when Lenny’s lack of greenkeeping skills could result in a loss for the club at the forthcoming Pennant Day. Director David Caesar’s first feature reflects a nostalgia for a simpler time and place.

results.title: Greening the land
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Battle for the planet”.
Anil Agarwal, India’s foremost environmentalist, presents this strong case for community involvement in reafforestation to control and wind back the spreading deserts in Third World countries. He takes us into two regions: the Sudan in Africa and the Himalayas in Northern India. In the Sudan, an old man in a small village tells how he remembers when the region was covered in left in the region. In the Himalayas, the famous Chipko movement led by Brother Bhatti has had great success in preventing the further destruction of forests in north India.
